email.title: 1.5.1 Email Writer
email.context: Professional workplace communication requiring polite, concise, and collaborative tone.
email.template:
```markdown
Context:
I work in a professional environment and often need to email my coworkers. The tone should be polite, concise, and collaborative. The emails may involve updates, requests, or responses.

Objective:
Help me draft or edit an email that communicates my message effectively while maintaining professionalism and clarity.

Style:
Use a tone that is:

Courteous but direct
Neutral and professional (avoid overly formal or casual phrasing)
Concise â€” focus on clarity and purpose
Culturally appropriate for workplace communication

Task:
Write or refine my email to ensure it:

Has a clear subject line and logical structure
Opens with context or appreciation
States the main message or request succinctly
Ends with a polite closing and call to action (if needed)
Optionally includes a short sign-off

Action:
I will provide my rough draft or main points. You will return a polished, professional email version ready to send.

Result:
A final email draft that is polite, concise, and professional â€” suitable for workplace communication.
```

I need to email my manager about requesting time off next week for a family event.
I want to be professional but also show that I've planned ahead.

tpm.title: 1.5.2 Technical Project Manager
tpm.context: First-principles analysis for IT/software projects with structured technical planning. See 2.2 Co-STAR Framework for comprehensive breakdown of this prompt structure.
tpm.sampleInput: We need to build a customer feedback system that collects reviews, analyzes sentiment, and generates reports for our e-commerce platform. The system should handle 10,000+ reviews per day and integrate with our existing CRM.
tpm.sampleOutput:
1. **Task Summary:** Build a scalable customer feedback analysis system for e-commerce platform

2. **Core Problem / Goal:** Collect, process, and analyze customer reviews to generate actionable insights

3. **First Principles Breakdown:**
   - Data collection (reviews) â†’ Processing (sentiment analysis) â†’ Output (reports)
   - Scale requirement: 10,000+ reviews/day
   - Integration requirement: Existing CRM system

4. **Minimum Viable Components:**
   - Review collection API
   - Sentiment analysis engine
   - Report generation service
   - CRM integration layer

5. **Technical To-Do / Staged Plan:**
   - **Stage 1: Foundation** â€” API design, database schema, basic collection

6. **Key Success Metrics:**

legal.title: 1.5.4 Legal Counsel
legal.template:
```markdown
**Role**: You are a senior legal counsel with expertise in Hong Kong contract law.

**Task**: Review the following sales contract clause, identify potential legal and commercial risks under Hong Kong law, and provide suggested revisions.

**Clause to Review**:
"Party B shall deliver the goods within 3 working days after receiving the payment. In case of delayed delivery, a penalty of 0.1% of the contract amount per day will be charged."

**Output Requirements**:

Identify and explain each potential risk point, considering enforceability under Hong Kong law

Provide references to relevant legal principles or case law where applicable (e.g., penalty vs. liquidated damages doctrine)

Draft a revised version of the clause to mitigate risk and improve enforceability

Format: Present your analysis in bullet points; use bold to highlight key legal issues or recommendations
```
legal.sampleInput: Review this clause: "Party B shall deliver the goods within 3 working days after receiving the payment. In case of delayed delivery, a penalty of 0.1% of the contract amount per day will be charged."
legal.riskAnalysis:
â€¢ **Penalty Clause Risk**: The 0.1% daily penalty may be deemed unenforceable under Hong Kong law as it could constitute a penalty rather than liquidated damages

â€¢ **Uncertainty in "Working Days"**: The term "working days" is ambiguous and may lead to disputes about calculation methods

â€¢ **No Force Majeure Protection**: The clause lacks protection for circumstances beyond Party B's control
legal.legalReferences:
â€¢ **Dunlop Pneumatic Tyre Co Ltd v New Garage & Motor Co Ltd [1915]**: Establishes the test for distinguishing penalties from liquidated damages
â€¢ **Hong Kong Contract Law**: Penalties are unenforceable if they are extravagant and unconscionable
legal.revisedClause: "Party B shall deliver the goods within 3 business days (Monday to Friday, excluding public holidays) after receiving the payment. In case of delayed delivery due to Party B's fault, liquidated damages of 0.05% of the contract amount per day will be charged, subject to a maximum of 5% of the total contract value. This provision shall not apply in cases of force majeure or circumstances beyond Party B's reasonable control."

items.title: Accurate wording
items.description: Use standard vocabulary, action verbs, and correct grammar.
items.exampleBad: Tell me about this year's worldwide soccer game.
items.exampleGood: In which country will the 2024 FIFA World Cup be held?

items.title: Specificity
items.description: Supply industry, metrics, and any background that narrows the answer.
items.exampleGood: Analyze this marketing portfolio with a focus on brand positioning and market share.

items.title: Conciseness
items.description: Trim filler; crisp prompts are easier for the model to follow.
items.exampleBad: Can you help me write something about AI and ML including many industriesâ€¦
items.exampleGood: Write a 200-word overview of AI uses in healthcare, finance, and tech.

items.title: Unambiguity
items.description: Explain what you mean when multiple interpretations exist.
items.example: Specify the company, timeframe, or metric you want.

items.title: Helpful guidance
items.description: Share evaluation criteria, tone, or tools the model can use.
items.example: Add scoring rubrics, references, or checklists to keep answers aligned.

items.title: Structure & examples
items.description: Present numbered steps or sample outputs so the model mirrors them.
items.example: Use Co-STAR or provide one good answer for the model to imitate.

security.title: Data security & privacy
security.intro: Treat prompts like production inputâ€”protect people and data.

areas.title: Input
areas.description: Avoid sending personal or confidential details unless contracts allow it.

areas.title: Output
areas.description: Models can leak patterns or confidential insightâ€”review before sharing.
areas.actions: Add post-generation filters and human review for critical cases.

areas.title: Abuse & access
areas.description: Limit who can run prompts and monitor for misuse.
areas.actions: Use MFA, rate limits, audits, and prompt guardrails.

areas.title: Storage
areas.description: Lock down saved prompts and responses.
areas.actions: Encrypt at rest and apply least-privilege permissions.

takeaways.title: Key takeaways
points: Structure guides output; frameworks like Co-STAR help.
Context winsâ€”share role, background, and examples.
Protect data at every step before productionizing.
Leverage free and internal resources to experiment faster.
